title: Shabana Mahmood considers chemical castration for serious sex offenders
snippets:
Justice secretary expected to back radical sentencing reforms, including use of libido-suppressing drugs in England and Wales

Shabana Mahmood, the lord chancellor, is considering mandatory chemical castration for the most serious sex offenders, according to government sources.

The minister’s department is planning to expand a pilot to 20 regions as part of a package of “radical” measures to free thousands of prisoners and ease prison overcrowding in England and Wales.

Ensure custodial sentences under 12 months are only used in exceptional circumstances.

Extend suspended sentences to up to three years and encourage greater use of deferred sentences for low-risk offenders.

Give courts greater flexibility to use fines and ancillary orders like travel, driving and football bans.

Allow probation officers to adjust the level of supervision based on risk and compliance with licence conditions.

Expand specialist domestic abuse courts to improve support for victims.

Expand tagging for all perpetrators of violence against women and girls.

Improve training for practitioners and the judiciary on violence against women and girls.

Change the statutory purposes of sentencing so judges and magistrates must consider protecting victims as much as they consider punishment and rehabilitation when passing sentences.

Continue reading...
titles: Shabana Mahmood considers chemical castration for serious sex offenders
summary: Shabana Mahmood, the UK's justice secretary, is contemplating implementing mandatory chemical castration for severe sex offenders as part of broader sentencing reforms aimed at reducing prison overcrowding in England and Wales. These reforms also include limiting custodial sentences under 12 months, extending suspended sentences, and increasing the use of fines and bans. Additionally, the plan involves expanding specialist domestic abuse courts and tagging for violence perpetrators, enhancing training on violence against women, and adjusting sentencing purposes to prioritize victim protection
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive because it gives the reader a deeper understanding of the potential changes in the UK's justice system. It reports on a possible solution to prison overcrowding and highlights the efforts to prioritize victim protection. It also increases awareness about the different approaches being considered to tackle serious crimes.

title: Watch These Palo Alto Networks Stock Levels After Post-Earnings Slide
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Palo Alto Networks shares tumbled on Wednesday as the cybersecurity giant’s mostly in-line guidance overshadowed quarterly results that surpassed Wall Street expectations. 
  • The stock had trended modestly higher after breaking out above the upper trendline of a descending broadening formation in late April. More recently, the relative strength index had tracked toward overbought levels.
  • Investors should watch key support levels on Palo Alto's chart around $180 and $165, while also monitoring key resistance levels near $205 and $240.


Palo Alto Networks (PANW) shares tumbled on Wednesday as the cybersecurity giant’s mostly in-line guidance overshadowed quarterly results that surpassed Wall Street estimates, indicating investors may have been looking for more.

The stock fell nearly 7% to close at around $181, pushing it slightly into negative territory year-to-date. Shares are still up about 25% from last month's low, as investors continue to assess the company’s platformization strategy, which involves transitioning customers to a cloud-based cybersecurity platform.

 Below, we take a closer look at Palo Alto’s chart and use technical analysis to identify price levels worth watching out for.

Recent Breakout in Focus

Palo Alto shares had trended modestly higher after breaking out above the upper trendline of a descending broadening formation in late April.

More recently, the relative strength index tracked toward overbought levels, indicating building price momentum ahead of the cybersecurity giant’s quarterly results. That bullish sentiment ended abruptly on Wednesday.

Let’s identify several support and resistance levels on Palo Alto’s chart that investors will likely be watching.

Key Support Levels to Watch

The first lower level to watch sits around $180. This area, currently located roughly midway between the 50- and 200-day moving averages, may provide support near a trendline that connects a range of corresponding price action on the chart stretching back to last September.

Selling below this level raises the possibility for a steeper drop to the $165 level. Investors could seek longer-term buy-and-hold opportunities in this region near January’s retracement to the 200-day MA, which also closely aligns with troughs that formed on the chart during September and October last year.

Key Resistance Levels to Monitor

Upon a resumption of the stock’s recent move higher, it’s worth monitoring the $205 area. This area may provide overhead selling pressure near a series of peaks that developed on the chart between November and February.

Finally, investors can forecast a potential price target above the stock’s record high by using the measuring principle, a technique that analyzes chart patterns to project future price moves.

When applying the analysis to Palo Alto’s chart, we calculate the distance of the descending broadening formation from its low to high and add that amount to the pattern’s breakout point. For instance, we add $64 to $176, which projects a target of $240.

The comments, opinions, and analyses expressed on Investopedia are for informational purposes only. Read our warranty and liability disclaimer for more info.

As of the date this article was written, the author does not own any of the above securities.
titles: Watch These Palo Alto Networks Stock Levels After Post-Earnings Slide
summary: Palo Alto Networks' shares dropped nearly 7% to close at around $181 on Wednesday, despite the cybersecurity company surpassing Wall Street expectations for its quarterly results. The decline was attributed to its guidance, which was mostly in line with forecasts, failing to excite investors. The stock's recent performance had shown signs of bullish momentum, breaking out from a descending broadening formation in late April and approaching overbought levels. Technical analysis suggests watching for key support levels at $180 and $165, and resistance levels near $205 and $240. Investors had bee
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful information for investors interested in Palo Alto Networks, offering insights on the company's stock performance and potential future trends. However, it lacks depth in terms of the company's overall business strategy or the wider implications of its financial results.

title: Intel’s Memory Leak Nightmare: 5,000 Bytes per Second in the Hands of Hackers
snippets: Computer scientists at ETH Zurich have uncovered a serious flaw in Intel processors that could let attackers steal sensitive information by exploiting how modern chips predict upcoming actions. Using specially designed sequences of instructions, hackers can bypass security boundaries and gradually read the entire memory of a shared processor. This vulnerability affects a wide range [...]
titles: Intel’s Memory Leak Nightmare: 5,000 Bytes per Second in the Hands of Hackers
summary: Researchers at ETH Zurich discovered a significant vulnerability in Intel processors, allowing hackers to steal sensitive information at a rate of 5,000 bytes per second. This flaw exploits the processors' predictive actions, enabling attackers to bypass security measures and access the entire memory of a shared processor. The issue presents a serious security concern for devices using affected Intel chips.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about a significant security vulnerability in Intel processors, which can help readers understand the risks associated with using devices with affected chips. However, it does not report on any solutions or improvements being made to address the issue, nor does it provide actionable insights for readers to protect themselves.
